posts.title: Two men found guilty of cutting down famous Sycamore Gap tree.
top_comments: Wanton destruction for destructions' sake. They cut a tree down *because* it was iconic, no other reason. Just to break a thing that people enjoyed. Purely selfish.

After reading the online reactions the two men were sending each other texts saying their critics "didnt have the minerals" to do what they did. They cut down a tree in the middle of nowhere at night and these pair of cunts think they pulled off a heist in a Guy Ritchie movie.
What absolute morons, ruining their lives for no reason at all. Enjoy the loss of your business, income, and any reputation you may have had. Plus possibly prison. Idiots.
I live on the other side of the planet and this really piss me off. I always wanted to go see Hadrians wall and this a stop I’ll make.
They deserve to go to jail for this.

Drove thirty miles through a storm just to make the world a little uglier.

You fuckers, my faith in humanity is already on fumes

Daniel Graham, 39, and Adam Carruthers, 32

Fucking useless pieces of shit. It’s not even like it was a few dumb teens. Throw away the key, these people are fucked
Grown men doing something like that,, pathetic. They should have to pay for their destruction for the rest of their lives.
I’m glad they found these guys and convicted them.
I saw the tree three weeks before it was cut down. Glad I got to see it before this happened. Waited my whole life to see it.

posts.title: US grants asylum to 54 white Afrikaner South Africans, reports say
top_comments:
>On Thursday, US officials were trying to arrange a charter flight to land at Dulles international airport, with commercial flights being assessed as an alternative, NPR reported, citing unnamed sources.

>The Department of Health and Human Services will help the South Africans with “housing … basic home furnishings, essential household items … groceries, weather-appropriate clothing, diapers, formula, hygiene products and prepaid phones,” according to a memo seen by the New York Times.

I just don't know where to begin. They may, in fact, face discrimination. Maybe even violence. And that's terrible. But rolling out the red carpet for these people while Donald Trump, all by himself, cancelled 100,000 asylum claims is beyond the pale.
I didn't think we needed more obvious evidence that this country has been hijacked by white supremacists but here we are.

It was never about legal versus illegal immigration.

It has always been about racism.
💯  Elon Musk and Peter Thiel,  fucking nazis

I thought they hated giving free handouts to migrants. If what the NY Times found is true then what's all this:

>The Department of Health and Human Services will help the South Africans with “housing … basic home furnishings, essential household items … groceries, weather-appropriate clothing, diapers, formula, hygiene products and prepaid phones,” according to a memo seen by the New York Times.

The fucking hypocrisy.

So let me get this straight, when it's POC looking for asylum in America its bad. But when it's white people, its good? And not to mention all the free shit their getting as well? Hypocrisy of the highest order.

Literally can’t make this shit up 💀

-asylum seekers from Mexico: NOO 😡 NOT CITIZENSS😠🤬GET OUT😤

-white asylum seekers from South Africa: oh no! 😥 my sweet poor babies 😩 let me welcome you with open arms 🤗

So to summerize:

He asked the Supreme Court to allow him to deport 100,000 South American asylum seekers who have already been living here while simultaneously bending over backward to allow 54 *white* afrikaners from South Africa to come reside in the United States? Absolutely no one can convince me that this administration isn't racist as fuck.

Meanwhile We abandoned Afghans, many of whom assisted the US military, who are literally IN HIDING?

https://apnews.com/article/afghanistan-refugees-qatar-trump-immigration-refugee-ban-006240c5700fa7a95e4c2f2dcf66ad4f


Question- How many Afrikaner/White South Africans immigrate to the US per year normally? 

This reminds me of the case of the German family who applied for US asylum because they homeschooled and that is/was illegal in Germany.

BTW- It usually takes years of waiting and vetting to be granted asylum. This. is. a. joke.
They will be on the first plane back once they realise they can't get a domestic worker for what they're used to paying in SA.

posts.title: Cigma denies man life-saving lung transplant shortly before scheduled operation.
top_comments:
Cigna has done this *exact same thing before* in 2023, but changed their mind after a social media outcry: https://clearhealthcosts.com/blog/2023/11/cigna-denies-transplant-then-approves-after-social-media-campaign/

Unfortunately the lungs were no longer available for transplant after they changed their mind. She did eventually get the transplant and was reported to be cancer free several months later in 2024. 

Supporters of the woman who was denied care emailed the CEO directly: david.cordani@cigna.com.
Is this one of those “death panels” they warned us about?

"Our coverage guidelines are grounded in national clinical standards to help ensure the best possible outcomes for patients."

…and we’ve decided that the best possible outcome for this patient would be for him to just fucking die already.
A man battling stage 4 lung cancer was preparing to fly across the country for a life-changing double-lung transplant when his insurance company denied him coverage.
I had a knee surgery denied because I didn’t try not having knee surgery long enough. My meniscus was shredded and stuck between the joint. Fuck these ghouls.
For the record, the company is Cigna, not Cigma.  It’s the same company that *my* company uses to provide our health insurance with the $5,000 deductible.  It’s fucking worthless.
I’m enjoying the fact that several people are calling it Cigma because the title had a typo
Cigna is the same company that denied a 17-yr old girl a liver in 2007.

United healthcare denied my mother in law's mastectomy when she was diagnosed with breast cancer. She had the much less expensive lumpectomy. The reason the doctors prefer to do a mastectomy is because it's easy to miss some cancer cells doing a lumpectomy and then the cancer can return. Sure enough, they missed some and the cancer came roaring back. Only this time it spread well beyond her breasts, and by the time they realized it was back it had spread to inoperable areas. She has to do a monthly chemo pill to keep it under control and is constantly having to chase the newest treatment once hers stops working. Recently her hair all fell out, after decades of hanging on. We are very lucky to still have her after 20 years post diagnosis, but this cancer will kill her. She is only in her early 60's. We should have another 20 years with her but I don't think she will be able to beat the cancer for that long given her recent decline. United healthcare gave her a death sentence years ago and we just keep trying to postpone it. She could have gone into remission, but instead she's had to live with cancer for decades and will die prematurely from it. We need single payer healthcare in this country YESTERDAY.

For-profit healthcare in the US needs to die.  
  
**As an institution, for-profit healthcare in the US has externalized costs of at least 45,000 deaths per year, the suffering of countless more, and the stress of virtually every citizen. We cannot continue to accept this institutionalized carnage that does more harm to the populace than we can quantify. Any imaginable for-profit institution would be shut down by a remotely sensible society far before they managed to rack up such a destructive, bloodstained track record as has the modern for-profit American medical system**  
  
For-profit healthcare in the US needs to die.

posts.title: The aluminum sector isn't moving to the U.S. despite tariffs — due to one key reason
top_comments: "The barrier remains the lack of access to competitively priced, long-term power, according to the industry"
No serious company will make a snap decision to finance a huge investment of moving production to the states because of tariffs that were put up overnight.

Aluminum is really a fascinating thing as it's really pretty recent that we've had the means to extract it.  Bauxite is quite common but extracting the metals from the ore is very difficult.  So difficult that until we figured out how to use electrolysis to do it, the price of aluminum was higher than that of gold.  The common story that is told (I'm unsure how factually accurate it is) was that Napoleon the third would use aluminum flatware at banquets while other dignitaries would use gold cutlery.

With electrolysis, extraction of aluminum ( and gallium as well, but gallium is not as useful in general applications) from bauxite became easier and the process has only improved.  The process was invented only in 1890s.  The main issue with it being that it does require quite a lot of electricity, which is why Canada produces a lot of it.  They have abundant hydro electric power to perform the electrolysis process fairly inexpensively.

A local (NW US) aluminum smelter closed a few years ago. It was built in the 1950’s and hadn’t been significantly modernized. Periodic plans to reopen it by investment funds have involved large government subsidies and non-existent cheap subsidized power.

Ultra cheap hydroelectric power in the NW US has been gone for many years. Regional economic growth and much higher demand have consumed the once abundant cheap power, and caused all of the legacy aluminum plants to close.

> Sweeping tariffs imposed by U.S. President Donald Trump on imported aluminum are reshaping global trade flows and inflating costs for American consumers. But they are falling short of their primary goal: to revive domestic aluminum production.
Instead, rising costs, particularly skyrocketing electricity prices in the U.S. relative to global competitors, are leading to smelter closures rather than restarts.

Adding even more financial stress on an already struggling population.

That's fundamentally what's wrong with this tariff policy. They want to bring back low profit industries (seemingly just out of nostalgia), while they could be focusing on sectors that they already have competitive advantages (like AI). It's literally wasting energy with something less profitable

This is really interesting and I'm glad that this got posted,  but what even is this title? There's been so much posts like this on Reddit lately where you don't know what it's alluding to I'll clickbait style and it's really frustrating.

Trump's claims and behavior shows policies that assumes the only thing preventing manufacturing growth in the US is overly competitive pricing. There's little structural awareness: whether it's sourcing raw/semi processed materials, setup investment costs, or ancillary infrastructure, there's broad issues which blanket tariffs are actually doing more to impede new manufacturing rather than encourage it. Not to mention attacking international goodwill which reduces demand for American products, and increases demand for competitors' products.
But I thought in his meeting with Carney he said they were building aluminum and steel plants like never before and they don’t need Canada?
Considering past initiatives Donnie's "fix" to such a conundrum would be to reset all bank asset balances to zero.

posts.title: Two arrested after neighbors try to stop ICE agents from detaining Worcester mother
top_comments: Something tells me it's going to be a hot, hot summer.

"Terrible things are happening outside. At any time of night and day, poor helpless people are being dragged out of their homes. They’re allowed to take only a knapsack and a little cash with them, and even then, they’re robbed of these possessions on the way. Families are torn apart; men, women and children are separated. Children come home from school to find that their parents have disappeared. Women return from shopping to find their houses sealed, their families gone." - Anne Frank, The Diary of a Young Girl.
I like how this neighborhood is full of people that are ride-or-die, should serve as an example for us all. I want to see some videos of this.
They're charging her with assault and battery with a dangerous weapon for throwing a drink at the cops. What a fucking crock of shit.
Not unprecedented. [Boston, 1834](https://newenglandhistoricalsociety.com/boston-slave-riot-1854/)

Video of it here:

[https://www.reddit.com/r/PublicFreakout/comments/1ki292o/crowd\_in\_worcester\_ma\_tries\_to\_interfere\_with\_ice/](https://www.reddit.com/r/PublicFreakout/comments/1ki292o/crowd_in_worcester_ma_tries_to_interfere_with_ice/)

It's a chaotic scene, but it looks like one of the arrests is happening as they pull a woman away. Crazy how many cops they had out there--totally intimidating and unnecessary.

My great grandmother once held off US Army troops with a broom to buy time for her Japanese neighbors to put their house in trust, thus keeping it out of government hands; they were some of the few who had a home to come back to after the war thanks in part to her. 

I hope that I'll be as brave as she was and these people are when the time comes.

"Two arrested including a candidate for Worcester School Committee" 

Man, that's the kind of arrest  you can point to the show that you have empathy and are willing to stand up for those who are marginalized in our society. She should be elected by a landslide. 

 In some circles it would be seen as a bonus to stand up to this tyrannical regime.

Also noticed that one woman was charged with reckless endangerment of a child, what absolute b*******. The only ones recklessly endangering children are the agents and police themselves.
This is how “hiding people in the attic” began…
Well, I'm convinced. This is the time. We fight ICE in every neighborhood at this point.

posts.title: ‘Tone deaf’: US tech company responsible for global IT outage to cut jobs and use AI
top_comments: can not wait for "Vibe security" to become the new trend.
A major IT company is tone deaf? How unusual.

They aren't. They are using AI as an excuse to lay off employees. AI isn't there yet. Not even close. It makes some devs more efficient, but it won't replace very many people. It still makes terrible mistakes all the time and ChatGPTs code never runs right out of the box. I use it mainly to generate unit test dummy data, and it fucks up a lot.

Why use AI as an excuse to lay off employees? It's an easy win. Make investors excited, and less backlash. Companies lay off employees all the time.
I'm sure this isn't so much tone deaf as it is apathetic and greedy. Let's not bless them the credit of ignorance. They knew what they were doing; cutting corners to get richer.

Offshore IT - yup!
Replace IT with AI - yup!
Fuck your employees - yup!
Fuck your customers - yup!
Good luck with that, assholes.
What could possiblie go wrong.
Well, guess I can stop looking at CrowdStrike as a vendor. Least they make it easier to choose!
How to lose the rest of your customer base with this one easy trick

Riiight, “AI” did this, not the epic fuckup that probably lost them a significant portion of their customers and future revenue.

AI is the new excuse they’re giving when laying people off, whether it’s really true or not. “Don’t be mad at me, be mad at AI!”

I don’t buy it.
Can’t wait till it happens again

posts.title: DEA impersonators targeting medical offices and everyday citizens with fake fines
top_comments:
Please pay your fine in Apple Gift cards.

dummy"okay"
The best way to determine if it’s a scam is if the agent is wearing a body cam. Then you know for sure it’s a scam.

>"Where they get a call from someone saying they're with the DEA and that a rental car has been found on the border that was written in your name and it contains a ton of drugs and if you don't pay this fine, we're going to come after you and lock you up," McNeal said.

It's always urgent and they front load the conversation with the threat of fines and/or arrest. 

>“Part of it was when he hung up, he said ‘God bless America,’” said Gladys Moore, a practice administrator at Affiliated Troy Dermatologists.

The 'God bless America' is pretty solid. Scammers are bad, but that's a pretty good way to end the call.
Look at how ICE operates and dresses, no reason to think they are nothing more than random thugs trying to harm you.  Oh, hmmm...
Oh, can I just come get my drugs back then?

I was called by my local “Sheriff’s office” saying I had a warrant out for my arrest for not showing up for jury duty.  They claimed they had a copy of the notice that I had received and signed.  I told them to go ahead and send a cop to arrest me.  I’m still waiting….
"What's my name and address, then?"
God bless America, right before asking for $10K? That’s a new level of bold

I answer the phone in a new language every time and my scammer calls have dropped from 10 a week to 1 a month.  I'm doing Klingon on the next one.

nuqneH...    'e' yIjatlhqa'...             not yap wa' Hol

Hello,...     Please say that again...     One language is never enough

There are a lot of very confused scammers when they get done talking to me.
It’s gotten to the point where I will immediately hang up the moment I hear an Accent. And I will cuss at them before I hang up if it is a crappy *American* accent.

posts.title: UnitedHealthcare sued by shareholders over reaction to CEO's killing
top_comments:
The group, which is seeking unspecified damages, argued that the public backlash prevented the company from pursuing “the aggressive, anti-consumer tactics that it would need to achieve” its earnings goals.

That's all you really need to know about this company and its shareholders.

From the Article 

> A group of investors sued UnitedHealthcare Group on Wednesday, accusing the company of misleading them after the killing of its CEO, Brian Thompson.

> The class action lawsuit — filed in the Southern District of New York — accuses the health insurance company of not initially adjusting their 2025 net earning outlook to factor in how Thompson’s killing would affect their operations.

> The investors described this as “materially false and misleading,” pointing to the immense public scrutiny the company and the broader health insurance industry experienced in the wake of Thompson’s killing.

> The group, which is seeking unspecified damages, argued that the public backlash prevented the company from pursuing “the aggressive, anti-consumer tactics that it would need to achieve” its earnings goals.

I am wondering what this means

"argued that the public backlash prevented the company from pursuing “the aggressive, anti-consumer tactics that it would need to achieve” its earnings goals."

Are they angry they can't be assholes? Am I missing something?
I suspect the problem. causing the loss of income, is not because the CEO is dead, but because of the bad publicity that people now see about United Healthcare.
Who are these shareholders and where do they live? So we can avoid them at all costs.

Why would they phrase it as anti-consumer instead of something like “cost preserving“ tactics, or “waste reduction“ tactics like they would usually do. Does it help their case to phrase it that way? Is it directly referencing something UHC did after the ceo was killed?

> On Dec. 3 — a day before Thompson was fatally shot — the company issued guidance that included net earnings of $28.15 to $28.65 per share and adjusted net earnings of $29.50 to $30.00 per share, the suit notes. And on January 16, the company announced that it was sticking with its old forecast.

> The group, which is seeking unspecified damages, argued that the public backlash prevented the company from pursuing “the aggressive, anti-consumer tactics that it would need to achieve” its earnings goals.


They are arguing that UnitedHealth should have adjusted their earnings forecast in response to the shooting.
Sure is a bold move to see someone killed for anti-consumer tactics and sue because they weren't anti-consumer enough. Someone feels too safe

And I thought the new pope would be the least interesting story of the day 

>The legal defense fund for Mangione surpassed the $1 million mark in donations on Tuesday

But at least it has a happy ending

For a moment I honestly thought the lawsuit would be about how the company's public image was hurt by the negative publicity it received for being so evil.

Instead, stockholders are suing the company for not being evil enough.  Did I read that right?

posts.title: DEA impersonators targeting medical offices and everyday citizens with fake fines
top_comments:

dummy"okay"
The best way to determine if it’s a scam is if the agent is wearing a body cam. Then you know for sure it’s a scam.

>"Where they get a call from someone saying they're with the DEA and that a rental car has been found on the border that was written in your name and it contains a ton of drugs and if you don't pay this fine, we're going to come after you and lock you up," McNeal said.

It's always urgent and they front load the conversation with the threat of fines and/or arrest. 

>“Part of it was when he hung up, he said ‘God bless America,’” said Gladys Moore, a practice administrator at Affiliated Troy Dermatologists.

The 'God bless America' is pretty solid. Scammers are bad, but that's a pretty good way to end the call.
Look at how ICE operates and dresses, no reason to think they are nothing more than random thugs trying to harm you.  Oh, hmmm...
Oh, can I just come get my drugs back then?

I was called by my local “Sheriff’s office” saying I had a warrant out for my arrest for not showing up for jury duty.  They claimed they had a copy of the notice that I had received and signed.  I told them to go ahead and send a cop to arrest me.  I’m still waiting….
"What's my name and address, then?"
God bless America, right before asking for $10K? That’s a new level of bold

I answer the phone in a new language every time and my scammer calls have dropped from 10 a week to 1 a month.  I'm doing Klingon on the next one.

posts.title: The aluminum sector isn't moving to the U.S. despite tariffs — due to one key reason
top_comments: "The barrier remains the lack of access to competitively priced, long-term power, according to the industry"
No serious company will make a snap decision to finance a huge investment of moving production to the states because of tariffs that were put up overnight.

Aluminum is really a fascinating thing as it's really pretty recent that we've had the means to extract it.  Bauxite is quite common but extracting the metals from the ore is very difficult.  So difficult that until we figured out how to use electrolysis to do it, the price of aluminum was higher than that of gold.  The common story that is told (I'm unsure how factually accurate it is) was that Napoleon the third would use aluminum flatware at banquets while other dignitaries would use gold cutlery.

With electrolysis, extraction of aluminum ( and gallium as well, but gallium is not as useful in general applications) from bauxite became easier and the process has only improved.  The process was invented only in 1890s.  The main issue with it being that it does require quite a lot of electricity, which is why Canada produces a lot of it.  They have abundant hydro electric power to perform the electrolysis process fairly inexpensively.

A local (NW US) aluminum smelter closed a few years ago. It was built in the 1950’s and hadn’t been significantly modernized. Periodic plans to reopen it by investment funds have involved large government subsidies and non-existent cheap subsidized power.

Ultra cheap hydroelectric power in the NW US has been gone for many years. Regional economic growth and much higher demand have consumed the once abundant cheap power, and caused all of the legacy aluminum plants to close.

> Sweeping tariffs imposed by U.S. President Donald Trump on imported aluminum are reshaping global trade flows and inflating costs for American consumers. But they are falling short of their primary goal: to revive domestic aluminum production.
Instead, rising costs, particularly skyrocketing electricity prices in the U.S. relative to global competitors, are leading to smelter closures rather than restarts.

Adding even more financial stress on an already struggling population.

That's fundamentally what's wrong with this tariff policy. They want to bring back low profit industries (seemingly just out of nostalgia), while they could be focusing on sectors that they already have competitive advantages (like AI). It's literally wasting energy with something less profitable

This is really interesting and I'm glad that this got posted,  but what even is this title? There's been so much posts like this on Reddit lately where you don't know what it's alluding to I'll clickbait style and it's really frustrating.

Trump's claims and behavior shows policies that assumes the only thing preventing manufacturing growth in the US is overly competitive pricing. There's little structural awareness: whether it's sourcing raw/semi processed materials, setup investment costs, or ancillary infrastructure, there's broad issues which blanket tariffs are actually doing more to impede new manufacturing rather than encourage it. Not to mention attacking international goodwill which reduces demand for American products, and increases demand for competitors' products.
But I thought in his meeting with Carney he said they were building aluminum and steel plants like never before and they don’t need Canada?
Considering past initiatives Donnie's "fix" to such a conundrum would be to reset all bank asset balances to zero.

12 years later…
Tradition says the American flag will fly at half staff starting from the day of death until internment. We'll see if Donald Trump orders this.

>“What I worry about is that when problems are not addressed, people will not know who is responsible. And when the problems get bad enough ... some one person will come forward and say, ‘Give me total power and I will solve this problem.’ That is how the Roman republic fell,” Souter said in a 2012 interview.

He was a Republican Supreme Court Justice who made decisions on a case by case basis rather than mindlessly parroting the Republican party line, i.e., a vanishing species.

“Aww, not *Souter*!”

-Homer Jay Simpson
Waiting for Mitch McConnell to declare this obviously means 7 new SCOTUS appointments for Trump.

One of the GOATs, rest in peace.

He held on because of the debacle with Alito being forced on to the bench by the conservative GOP rebellion against W. He was terrified of what the GOP was becoming.

They aren't. They are using AI as an excuse to lay off employees. AI isn't there yet. Not even close. It makes some devs more efficient, but it won't replace very many people. It still makes terrible mistakes all the time and ChatGPTs code never runs right out of the box. I use it mainly to generate unit test dummy data, and it fucks up a lot.

Why use AI as an excuse to lay off employees? It's an easy win. Make investors excited, and less backlash. Companies lay off employees all the time.
I'm sure this isn't so much tone deaf as it is apathetic and greedy. Let's not bless them the credit of ignorance. They knew what they were doing; cutting corners to get richer.
